description: From a Scandinavian (North Germanic) language, akin to Icelandic flaustra (“to be flustered”).

entries.meaning: A state of being flustered; overwrought confusion.

verbs.description: fluster (third-person singular simple present flusters, present participle flustering, simple past and past participle flustered)

entries.meaning: (dated) To make hot and rosy, as with drinking.
(by extension) To confuse; befuddle; throw into panic by making overwrought with confusion.
examples: He seemed to get flustered when speaking in front of too many people.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be in a heat or bustle; to be agitated and confused.
